bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, February 20, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg congratulates Hench on his discovery of the Lazear letters and feels the war will revive interest in yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, February 20, 1942
div1.opener:
Y F.
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
February 20, 1942
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
In my yesterday's letter I neglected to
congratulate you on the splendid find you made in the
Lazear letters near Baltimore. I just wrote a note to
Gen. Truby and in it I expressed the hope that you would
have your manuscript on yellow fever ready for publi-
cation, inasmuch as the war has revived the whole in-
terest in the disease. For example, the recent order to
have all the men now fighting be vaccinated against it.
(I wonder if the reporter got that story mixed up because
I didn't know there was a vaccination possible in yellow
fever.)

Doris and I were invited to see “Porgy
and Bess last week, but inasmuch as she was not feeling
well I took her sister who was much thrilled at her first
New York theatre. If you get back here while the show is
still running I would advise you to see it as it is
thoroughly worth while even though you saw the original
production, and that some years ago.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg
2L. GAK:L
Dictated, but
not read.
